docs.comments:
This is a borehole network of Sacs-Evertson volumetric strain meters.

The Icelandic strain network was installed in 1979 as a collaborative venture between IMO and the Carnegie Institution of Washington, Department of Terrestrial Magnetism (CIW). IMO is responsible for the operation of the network, with operational support provided by CIW. The strainmeter network was initially intended to record crustal deformation caused by strong earthquakes in SISZ, but it has proved essential for monitoring volcanic eruptions of Hekla. The station BUR is positioned ~14.3 km north-west from the volcano's summit.

When originally installed, the Iceland network comprised seven stations - three of which are operational today. The strain meters were grouted into boreholes in and around the SISZ. A new strainmeter was installed in September 2010, in a purpose-drilled borehole ~5 km south-east of the summit of Hekla; it is estimated that this station (HEK) is at least five times more sensitive to magma movements than BUR. Alongside the installation of HEK, a network-wide upgrade of strain acquisition and telemetry hardware took place between 2010 and 2011. Further expansion of the strain network is planned in coming years.

docs.comments:
Short description: 
GEOFON operates a global seismic network,a seismological data centre and a global earthquake information service.The seismic network is operated and partly funded jointly with > 50 partner institutions worldwide. Stations are in principle located on all continents but with concentration in the EuroMed area and the Indian Ocean. Nearly all stations are online, in the Indian Ocean and the Mediterranean the data are transferred by VSAT. The GEOFON Data Archive holds not only the data of the permanent GEOFON network, but hosts also the data of other GFZ and those of many partner institutions. Also data sets from temporary seismic networks by GFZ and other institutions are stored and re-distributed.

------
A research group that works on geodetic data since 1994 for crustal deformation studies is involved in the Department of Geophysics & Geothermics of NKUA. The main research activity refers to the study of the ground deformation in Tectonic and Volcanic active areas of Greece using satellite geodesy (GPS) and Satellite Radar Interferometry. 

Several local GPS networks have been established in Greece (central Ionian Islands, and also along the islands of the Hellenic Volcanic Arc), which are periodically re-measured. Continuous GPS (CGPS) stations (1 Hz)  have been operating since 2005 in selected sites in the mainland of Greece (Athens-UoA1) and at Riolos (RLSO) in NW Peloponnese. The Real-time data are automatically processed on a daily basis using the Bernese Processing Engine (BPE), and time series of station coordinates are monthly produced. The final results may be  combined with other data, such as Interferometric (conventional, PSInSAR, Stacking InSAR),  geophysical, seismological, geochemical and tectonic, too. 

Data from the CGPS stations are also used on a daily basis to calculate the Total Electron Content (TEC) of the Ionosphere. TEC variation maps may be produced on a daily basis to explore the correlation of the Ionospheric anomalies associated with the probable occurrence of large magnitude earthquake(s), contributing thus to earthquake prediction research.

Currently, the INGV Section of Catania manages 4 different CGPS networks for volcano monitoring. Since 1995, we have realized 36 stations on Mt. Etna, 5 stations on Stromboli volcano, 7 on Vulcano-Lipari complex and 3 on Pantelleria Island. 
All these stations are linked to the master station of Catania through radio link. Almost all of these stations transmit data at 1Hz sampling rate and these data are also processed in real time and low latency (1 sec). The objectives of these network are two: i) to know day-by-day - or, for some volcanoes, second-by-second - the evolution of the ground deformation pattern for monitoring purposes and ii) to improve our knowledge of the internal processes of magma transfer form depth, focusing in particular those leading to potentially dangerous eruptions.

docs.ri_name: INGV - SISMOS (History and data of instrumental seismology)
data_archive_data_type: other: data tables with parametric instruments information
data_archive_software: Teseo2 (Teseo2 software for the digitation and vectorisation of the seismograms)
docs.data_archive_policy: special agreements for non Italian seismograms
docs.comments:
In 2001, the Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica e Vulcanologia (INGV) started an innovative project, Progetto SISMOS (i.e., SISMOgrammi Storici), to scan (i.e., convert into digital form for storage on a computer), at very high resolution, and archive seismological paper records and related material. The Italian Ministry for the Environment originally funded the project to encompass the digitization of seismogram records of the Italian seismic observatories and of associated bulletins for the period 18951984 (i.e., from the early age of seismometry to the advent of the digital era).
In 2002, the SISMOS activity was extended to seismograms and bulletins from observatories in 29 countries of the Euro-Mediterranean area through the the EuroSeismos project started in the framework of the activity of the European Seismological Commission Working Group on the History and Data of Instrumental Seismology,. The participating partners gather historical records at their observatories and send them to SISMOS for scanning, archiving, and dissemination. Since May 2006 SISMOS has been one of the facilities of the European project NERIES (Transnational Access 3). In the frame of NERIES SISMOS has indeed been recognised as the most advanced facility for the processing and analysis of analogue recordings of earthquakes in the period 1894-1985. During the 4 years of the NERIES project, the TA3 SISMOS received 20 applications of 16 countries 2 of them extra Europe. From the beginning of the SISMOS project until November 2010 more than 150,000 seismogram records have been scanned and made available. Similarly, historical seismic bulletins have been scanned and are available in Adobe PDF on the SISMOS Web site.

The current data set on which SISMOS operates consists of about 1000 relevant earthquakes. The scanning is carried out at 1016-dpi resolution using 3 Eskoscan 2636 flatbed professional scanners. The flow diagram in Figure below provides a schematic view of the processing carried out by SISMOS for scanning, archiving, and disseminating seismogram records. SISMOS has developed the Teseo2 software for the digitalisation and vectorisation of the seismograms (the process by which the tracing recorded in raster format is transformed into a series of segments connected between them such as to be reproduced).SISMOS recently has built a restoration laboratory acts upon the seismograms and the most interesting documents, which are particularly damaged and that risk definitively losing the information they contain. Furthermore SISMOS has realized a Laboratory for the restoration of historical instruments. Each instrument is associated with a digital chart complete with photographic images, drafted according to international catalographic norms. The charts will be gathered into catalogues that SISMOS will insert in its own Web pages dedicated to the virtual museum accessible to a diversified remote user base.

The main objective of GEODAC is to provide automatic analysis of GNSS time series to estimate the station velocity. Realistic error bars are computed through an approach that takes into account the temporal correlations that exist in the signal. 
After free registration, the user can upload his GNSS time-series which will be automatically processed and the results presented in the form of figures and tables that can be downloaded. The web service uses state-of art proprietary software developed at the University of Porto (Bos et al., 2008).
Free use for all registered users.
GEODAC can also archive GNSS data, from both episodic or permanent campaigns. 
Access to data archived depends on data owner policy. Upon request, data from UPorto stations is freely available as well as some historic data.

docs.ri_name: UAzores  Centre for Volcanology and Geological Risks Assessment
EERC - ICEMN  Icelandic Strong Motion Network
docs.ri_manager: Ragnar Sigbjornsson, Simon Olafsson and Benedikt Halldorsson
docs.comments:
The Earthquake Engineering Research Centre, University of Iceland, owns and operates the ICESMN network.
EERC is a leading edge international centre for developing the fundamental knowledge required for the planning and design of user friendly environment, focusing on protection and safety in earthquake prone regions; a unique centre of the University of Iceland with international recognition.
The EERC in its current form was established formally in 2000 founded on more than 30 years of active earthquake engineering research. EERC is located in Selfoss, roughly 60 km from the main campus of the University of Iceland in Reykjavik.  Activities at the Centre can be divided into three main groups: basic research, contractual industrial research and training of students for research and building facilities for engineering education. 
Research at the EERC at the University of Iceland is focused on the multi-disciplinary development of fundamental knowledge about societal earthquake effects. In particular the behaviour of structures in an earthquake prone environment using analytical, numerical and experimental methods. The emphasis is on earthquake engineering, applied mechanics and engineering seismology and the synergy between them. Ongoing research projects deal with: strong-motion monitoring and modelling; probabilistic and computational mechanics focusing on applications in earthquake, ocean and wind engineering; natural hazard and risk assessment; methods for the estimation of structural and non-structural damage in civil engineering structures and lifeline systems; loss and casualty estimation methodologies; planning; risk management.
The cornerstone of the scientific research activities at the EERC is its Icelandic Strong-motion Network (IceSMN). The Network was initiated in 1984 and is the only network of its kind in Iceland. The earthquake recordings that are provided by the network form the basis of the estimation of earthquake hazard and seismic risk in the country. The objectives of the network are to collect earthquake engineering data required for rational structural design and risk management. The network includes free-field stand-alone stations, a free-field array, and structural monitoring systems. The ICESMN has produced unique strong-motion data, which was non-existent before its establishment, but is now a part of the European Strong-motion Databank freely available via the Internet. The Network is still a unique scientific field laboratory in Iceland. The EERC also owns and operates the ICEARRAY, a new and permanent small-aperture strong-motion array in the South Iceland Seismic Zone.
	The objectives of the Icelandic Strong-motion Network are to collect data required for engineering seismological research as well as earthquake engineering research emphasising rational structural design and risk management. The locations of the stations in the Network were selected on the basis of geophysical information, the geographic distribution of the population, locations of industrial and power plants as well as the main lifeline systems.
The Icelandic Strong-motion Network consists of 58 stations measuring the ground response and structural response. The network consists of free-field stations, ground responce arrays, and structural monitoring systems. All ground response stations consist of three-component instruments and structural monitoring systems vary in single- vs. three-component configuration. At present, the network comprises a total of 254 components (equivalent to 84 three-component stations) and runs with a high degree of automation, using digital instruments. The stations are connected to a central computer that records detected events when the acceleration exceeds a prescribed threshold. Afterwards the recordings go through a routine processing and are then finally transferred to a database, which is freely accessible (http://www.ISESD.hi.is/). The ISESD was supported by the following European projects: European Strong-Motion Database (5th FP, Contract EVR1-CT-1999-40008) and European Strong-Motion Database Platform (4th FP, Contract ENV4-CT97-0397) (Ambraseys et al., 2004).

docs.comments: Acquire P and S-wave seismic reflection and refraction data for fault location and other structural and rock properties studies. By use of 3C component receivers and cables we can achieve full elastic seismic wave propagation studies. These studies will be a joint collaboration with the Geotechnical and Geophysics Department of TU Delft. The data can be made available to general public after publication of results.

Short Description:
ITSAK is almost concluding the installation of 120 new generation accelerographs in all over Greece (installing 9 more instruments). This network in conjunction to the previous installations (almost 150 of  ITSAK) will ensure an adequate coverage of the strong motion recording in Greece and surrounding areas. All the instruments will be connected to ITSAK through internet facilities and our main target would be the recording and the immediate processing. A newly developed data processing technique is applied for strong motion recordings. In addition to the aforementioned a site characterization of the Greek accelerographic stations is carried out in a joined project among ITSAK, Gi-NOA, Univ.of Patras, UCLA and USGS. Obviously the collaboration/connection of this network with corresponding ones in a European level could significantly contribute in engineering seismology and geotechnical engineering research.

docs.ri_name: CIVISA - Centre for Information and Seismovolcanic Surveillance of the Azores

docs.comments:
Real time monitoring of glacial rivers in Iceland started in 1998 after a catastrophic flood in Skeidara river, which discharges meltwater from the subglacial Grimsvotn caldera. The monitoring system has since then been expanded to cover most glacial rivers sourced from subglacial volcanoes and geothermal areas. The warning stations monitor water level, water temperature and electrical conductivity of the water. If the water level or the conductivity rises above a predefined value a warning is sent to the Icelandic Meteorological Office where a hydrologist evaluates the warning and, if needed, decides on an action.

The objectives of the system are to give early warnings of subglacial floods. It has proven to be useful and has given warnings of on-coming floods. One such warning  was for a flood from the Katla volcano in July 2011, were a bridge was swept away in a fast rising glacial flood (jokulhklaup) in the river Mulakvisl. Because of a warning from one of the stations, the road had been closed before the flood arrived.

The network used for volcano monitoring includes 13 hydrological stations.

Currently, the INGV Section of Catania manages 4 different CGPS networks for volcano monitoring. Since 1995, we have realized 36 stations on Mt. Etna, 5 stations on Stromboli volcano, 7 on Vulcano-Lipari complex and 3 on Pantelleria Island. 
All these stations are linked to the master station of Catania through radio link. Almost all of these stations transmit data at 1Hz sampling rate and these data are also processed in real time and low latency (1 sec). The objectives of these network are two: i) to know day-by-day - or, for some volcanoes, second-by-second - the evolution of the ground deformation pattern for monitoring purposes and ii) to improve our knowledge of the internal processes of magma transfer form depth, focusing in particular those leading to potentially dangerous eruptions.

equipment.specifics:
Measures gases which absorb in the IR region.  Includes a liquid nitrogen cooled MCT detector, and Ethernet interface.
The FTIR has a maximum spectral resolution of 0.5 cm-1. Detected gases include H2O, HF, HCl, CO2, CO, SO2, OCS, CH4 and SiF4.

Additional equipment:
An IR 5 source (infrared lamp) for active FTIR measurements; two 3 sighting telescopes for alignment; two custom-made tripods for the spectrometer and the IR source.

FTIR data analysis: FTIR-FIT, a custom-made infrared spectrum fitting software (licensed by M. Burton, INGV Pisa).

data_type: Time-series data collection in survey studies.
connectivity: Data is archived on the instrument computer. No transmission of data.

docs.comments:
The acquisition of this infrastructure has just started in 2012 and is expected to grow in coming years.

The overarching objective of conducting gas measurements is two-fold: 
(1) To add to the scientific understanding of the subsurface processes taking place in magmatic and geothermal systems and their associated degassing. Activity at many Icelandic volcanoes (including the most active ones such as Hekla, Katla, and Grmsvtn) involves a spectrum of magma compositions (from basaltic through dacitic). An accurate time-series of gas emissions may lead towards more sophisticated models for magma differentiation, movement and eruption style. The instruments are suitable for measurements during effusive and explosive activity (both magmatic and hydromagmatic). 
(2) To enhance the capacity of volcano monitoring and research into eruption forecasting and risk management in Iceland. Eruptions can sometimes commence without detectable geophysical warnings. It is possible that measurements of the gas composition at seismically quiet volcanoes such as Hekla may be able to detect earlier signals and hence provide a longer warning period.

equipment.type: Tools and materials used for the restoration operations: glue, brush, tissue paper, Japanese tissue paper, sponge, spatula and Teflon stick.

docs.other_details:
The restoration laboratory acts upon the seismograms and the most interesting documents, which are particularly damaged and that risk definitively losing the information they contain.  
Some reference guidelines have been established to deal with the most urgent problems.
The factors that need to be taken into account are the following: the constituent materials and manufacturing techniques (smoked, photographic, heat-sensitive paper, etc.)causes of deterioration (humidity, fungus attacks, tears, etc.)solutions by means of conservative intervention with the lowest possible impact.

docs.ri_name: UEvora  CGE Centro de Geofsica de vora
docs.comments: The CGE is organized in two main research lines. 1) Atmosphere and Hydrosphere and 2) Solid Earth. The Solid Earth attach three groups: 1) Active Tectonics & Risks, 2) Lithosphere, Mantle & Geological Resources and 3) Heritage & Archeometry.  The seismological team manages fixed and mobile observational means and cooperates in with national and international institutions to design, operate, process and analyse passive and active seismic operations. The main key topics by which each of the above mentioned groups may contribute to the advance of the state of art of the Solid Earth: Earthquake source seismology and seismic risk; 3D acoustic velocity models; Strong ground motion modeling; Instrumental seismology and seismic networks; Joint Inversion of seismic and geodesic data; Paleoseismology and active tectonics; Numerical modeling of fault systems; Applied geophysics; Physical properties of rocks;  Applied technologies for the characterization and conservation of geo-archaeomaterials and the reconstruction of ancient production technologies.

IDL manages fixed and mobile observational means and cooperates in with national and
international institutions to design, operate, process and analyse passive and active seismic
operations. IDL also maintains and develops Ocean Bottom Seismometers for long-term
recording, both short- and long-period.
This resources enable to perform cartography of the main inner earth discontinuities
by receiver functions analysis, different scales 3D tomographic models for the crust and
lithosphere, using body and surface waves and seismic ambient noise, evaluation of seismic
anisotropy at crustal and lithospheric scales.

The data comes from triggered instruments, both free-field and structural monitoring systems.
